parts.text: Good morning my name is Jane Campion and I'm here with Marianne around as though
recording visible lives oral histories of the disability experience
Good morning Mariana.
Good morning to you.
And tell me a little bit about where you're from.
I am from New York originally from Brooklyn. I have lived
in Staten Island for the last ten years and I am
currently. Retired from teaching I had a long career in the board of
education that I loved very much. Unfortunately eight years
ago I had to retire due to an illness.
I had a brain aneurysm. And it ruptured and I
was left disabled for. Quite a while and it took me a while to
get back on my feet and.
Mixing with people. OK What happened was I went out to dinner
one night and with my husband and some friends to a movie and
dinner and I had a.
Severe headache and I mention this because I want people to be aware of the signs
of an aneurysm because they are. Fatal in most cases.
Our the aneurysm ruptured and I was taken to the hospital. My
family was told that I would not make it through the night. I X. for a second
opinion. I got one. For thirty one days in intensive care and a
year and a half later I was pretty much back on my feet. But during that
time I realized what it truly meant to be disabled and
to have to depend on people and to not know what the future
would bring. And the only thing I learned was that it made me
stronger and gave me more resolve to do more in my life and
to accept that. This was an opportunity to really do
all the things I didn't have the time to do because I was busy raising my children and
working full time to doing so
. That's pretty much where I came from.
So let me ask you this do you feel that too. It's
what makes you different from other individuals do you feel that what happened to you makes you different in a
way from other individuals.
I have never felt different from anything.
And after I had the aneurysm and told everybody my story.
One of the things well I have to go to many doctors of course years of
doctors' follow up visits and I still tell one of the things
that was interesting was when it came to my vision I had to
tell them that I have no vision in my left eye.
And they would say Oh is that a result of the aneurysm and I would say no I always had
no vision in my left eye. Since this is the handwritten was a bonus.
So why.
When I think back. And realize that even though that
was a problem a disability I didn't know it was a disability
because much to my parents' credit they never treated it as such. They
took good care of me. I went to a specialist in Manhattan
at that time which was a big deal. People didn't go to specialists at that time your
local one took care of everything but I was never treated
differently and I just adapted. Now
today I'm sure I would probably have all kinds of surfaces. But in
reality I don't think I needed them because I adapted so well
and did so well in school despite that. But I never considered
myself having a problem.
My parents were overprotective but they were overprotective of all of their children not just
me.
And like I said I didn't really realize that
not having vision was not normal because my other eye was so
good that it compensated so when I had the aneurysm. My
biggest fear was waking up blind
. That really was I mean once I opened my eyes after the surgery with a clip the
prism and I could see I said everything is going to be OK and I
remember my daughter walking in and I was wiggling my fingers and my feet and
just looking around the room and showing my kids that I was OK The
nurse said to my daughter tell your mother to relax
. OK I just had to show them that I was going to be OK and
then it just redefines me
. I said you know what I always wanted to be a housewife and now I get to be a housewife I don't
have to go to work anymore I don't have to do anything. But of course that got old
really quick. I started watching you know cooking channels and everybody gained a
lot of weight and I said OK it's time to move on and I did.
So when you were first released from the hospital was there service personnel are certain what helped you
navigate around your surroundings.
I had a cane because I was very ill and stayed steady and it killed me
not to wear my high heels and. So I had to be
accompanied everywhere with why I couldn't go anywhere alone. And it did affect my
vision. I had a lot of trouble driving while I
couldn't drive but even being in a car everything was kind of distorted for me
and this went on for. Almost two years I had a hard time getting
used to things again. I went to physical therapy for a year and a
half straight three to four times a week.
And.
That's what made me stronger. Then I became involved in volunteer
activities because I knew I couldn't just stay home and get
worse and that's the thing I try to always encourage people who
have any kind of a problem to get out there and do things and
never let it stop you. And I know that's easier said than done because I do
have family members who are severely disabled with Huntington's
Disease and that kind of advice just doesn't work so. Then because
unfortunately they debilitate and it's
very hard to keep their spirits up. But I've always had a connection with
people with disabilities and it was kind of ironic that when I met my husband he
had a nineteen year old sister who was had. Huntington's
disease and afterwards his other brother and sister had it as
well and that passed on. Brother still alive.
So I know what it's like to see that disability and
. The only thing I could say about that is it takes its toll on the
family and. It's a very hard thing to live with
I want to ask you to tell me what you like about yourself
what do I like about myself.
I like that I could help out the people.
And is there anything you dislike about yourself or something you'd like to change
I don't think I really want to change much I wish I had more energy.
I wish there were more hours in the day I wish I could stay up past eleven and write
all night but I can only do and except what I can
do.
That's a big part of it.
I guess I need to accept that presently speaking your
life today. What makes.
Life difficult for you if anything.
What makes life difficult for some of my
anxieties.
About driving going to new places. That's a little tough
sometimes I feel a little overwhelmed. But fortunately I have a wonderful
husband who is my partner and my best friend and I have great kids too
so they're always around. I never feel alone.
Who is then the most important person in your life. My husband.
Can you tell me what the most important lesson you have learned from him is
There's nothing I can do.
Did the famous poet Ralph Waldo Emerson once wrote The only person you are
destined to become is the person you decide to be. Can you tell me what
person you decide to be.
Growing up. I always admired.
Powerful women and I remember going to the library at Saint symbolise and
taken out all the books. Eleanor Roosevelt.
Favorite was. Helen Keller.
I remember thinking that if she was blind and deaf. And
unable to speak.
Not having vision in one eye was nothing and that was really
always my hero.
When you change the sentence for me. I draw my strength from. God
. Tell me what would you like people to know about
individuals that have. Perhaps been afflicted with things that
you have like yourself that are individuals like yourself that are
diagnosed with the same brain aneurisms or
. Problems. What would you like people to know about
individuals.
I would like you to know that you shouldn't define a person by
any problems they may have. I don't want to be known as the girl who had the
brain aneurysm. I don't I've never wanted anyone to know that I had
vision problems. And until this day would shock people to
know that.
And when I tell them they cannot believe it but I am at an age where it doesn't matter
what I think I've defined myself enough not to be that
person.
You know when you grow up you know as a child children are always labeling
everybody. So in my opinion at the time I guess I just figured out it's best
not to say anything I just don't want to be known as a person that has
any types of issues. You just don't define anybody by
their problems. Look at the positives. Always. That's what I want
people to know.
We want to thank you for your beautiful story I feel honored that you have told us and is
willing to share in the visible alliance program. Is there anything else you would like to add
I think just for people to be tolerant of each other and to have
patience and to understand that everybody. Has
heart aches and. And problems and if you think they
don't you just don't know and that's the truth. We don't know what
anybody's lives are about. Truly walk in
the footsteps thank you so much Marianne and I think you know what
happened.
